Description: Body sherd of large Chian Grand Style pottery chalice or heavy chalice; cream slip; interior: glazed black with part of added white dot rosette and lotus bud in white outline with added red dots; below, two white bands; exterior: male figure, possibly a warrior (lower part of flesh-coloured leg and foot remaining) to left, on thick ground line; below, part of double guilloche pattern in handle zone.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The thickness of the sherd suggests that it may have come from a large chalice or heavy chalice. There is a modern drill hole on the break of the sherd. The fabric of the sherd was analysed by the Research Laboratory for Archaeology at Oxford. Using Ward's Method Cluster Analysis (WMCA) and Principal Components Analysis (PCA), it was found that the fabric originated in the Kampos plain in the east of the island of Chios (Jones 1986, p.286). It must also be pointed out that despite Jones' identification of the sherd as being in the Chalice Style, the sherd firmly belongs within the earlier Grand Style.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1354) (phase 2)
Jones 1986 / Greek and Cypriot Pottery: a Review of Scientific Studies (p.285, table 3.21, no.6)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
